unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Weight Loss
question_text:
A new weight-loss drug was on the market. Its slogan promised that people could lose $10\%$ of their weight in the first month. A research company wanted to test this and examine the difference between men and women. $64$ men and $66$ women were randomly selected from those using the drug. Of the men, $38$ said they lost $10\%$ of their weight and $28$ of the women said they did, too. A researcher wanted to know if more men lost weight.
Write the appropriate hypotheses to test this with $p_1$ representing the proportion of men who lost weight and $p_2$ representing the proportion of women who lost weight.

solution:
Solution

We need to write hypotheses for a test for the difference of two population proportions.

The null hypothesis states what we assume to be true. It is always written with an equals sign. It can be written as H0
: p1−p2=0
or H0
: p1=p2
. In this problem, the first form is used.

The alternative hypothesis states what we are trying to prove. It can be written with inequalities: >
, <
, or ≠
. Here, we are trying to show that the men's proportion is higher than the women's proportion. It could be written as Ha
: p1−p2>0
or Ha
: p1>p2
. The first form was used here.

So, Choice 'C' is correct.

Choice 'A' is incorrect because the signs of the two hypotheses are reversed.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because the null hypothesis has a less than sign when it should be an equal sign.
